channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: The religious context of the Minnesota shootings
item.description: The man charged with killing a Minnesota lawmaker and her husband is connected to a once-fringe religious movement that is now growing quickly, and which uses inflammatory anti-abortion rhetoric.

item.title: Radiolab celebrates 'Jaws' anniversary
item.description: To celebrate Jaws, this week WNYC's Radiolab is running a series called "Swimming in the Shadows."

item.title: Author Jason Reynolds talks about his latest book and the value of being a crier
item.description: Jason Reynolds writes young adult books that don't talk down to kids. His newest audio-only book is called Soundtrack. He talks with Rachel Martin about writing and the value of being a crier.

item.title: Many offices and professionals see a rise in spam paper faxes
item.description: These days, faxed documents mostly show up on your computer. But doctors and other professionals still rely on paper faxes. And they're getting lots of spam along with important documents.

item.title: Middle Eastern nations are caught in the flight path of the war between Israel and Iran
item.description: Israel and Iran have been trading attacks for five days. Jordan, Lebanon and other countries are caught in the flight path between the two.

item.title: Remembering Mother Emanuel, 10 years after racist attack on famed Charleston church
item.description: Charleston, S.C., reflects on 10 years since a racially motivated attack on the historic Emanuel AME church. A white supremacist killed 9 Black worshippers in 2015 in hopes of starting a race war.

item.title: South Korea's new president turns off loudspeakers at the border with North Korea
item.description: South Korea's new president's first move toward easing tensions with North Korea: switch off loudspeakers blaring propaganda and K-pop tunes over the border.

item.title: Gospel singer CeCe Winans reflects on her legendary career
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers talks with CeCe Winans, the best-selling female gospel artist in history, about her Tiny Desk performance and Black Music Month.

item.title: An intergenerational center works to connect nursing home residents and students
item.description: one small town in Kansas brings nursing home residents and students together as it tests a strategy for boosting quality of life across generations.

item.title: Backyard chicken rentals increase as egg prices fluctuate
item.description: When the price of eggs seesawed up and down, more people opted to buy chickens for their backyard and to make it an easier option: They rented them.
